comments.commentBody:
http://www.vox.com/2015/1/5/7463363/football-cte-high-school

Whether you believe CTE is some disease of weaklings or somehow by making changes to make people safe is bad, is the root of our country's weakness. Read this story

Guess what? 25 years from now football will either be gone or will only be played by the poor and helpless. The mommies in Greenwich, Chevy Chase, and New Trier will want to make sure their little boys don't suffer long term injury to their most important organ, their brains. And I cannot blame them! The daddies need to step up and day, " No, we are going to engage in different activities and sports. Period."

There are so many other and better sports to play. Go for it!

I don't buy the ignorance thing at all. His body looked like it had gone through a meat grinder after every match and Karen didn't connect that in any way to his symptoms. The only thing they could think of was to wonder if he was lazy. I agree with you about the child abuse but I think this is a classic case of it. And Patrick's father is just as guilty. Ignorance is no excuse in the law. But it's too late for Patrick isn't it?

Patrick's mother, Karen, probably can console herself by saying she did not understand at the time the damage caused by concussions. But knowing what we know today of the effects of multiple concussions on soft, developing brains, parents who still allow their young boys to play football are either in massive denial, or complicit in child abuse.

I've often been impressed by the mediaeval nature of football, the banners, the bands.  The horses are missing.  The nubile young ladies jumping around like poles dancers seem to complete a kind of coming-of-age fertility ritual at the height of hormonal realization.  I will always remember the writhing dancing at one half time to a Michael Jackson song (at the height of his troubles) to which we were treated, in between watching young men slam themselves into one another.  Where are the anthropologists.

The dynamic is this dysfunctional family is almost identical to an alcoholic family's. Addiction is a set of behaviors and the problem in this family started with a father who sounds very much like a charismatic, controlling alcoholic.

This is so sad. I do believe what you say, but there are so many girls that "just want to have fun" - but of the non-sexual kind. Do teenage guys ever feel satisfied with that? Somehow that disconnect runs through this discussion....

@What' this

" Good luck to everybody out there who play sports and if u sustain injury may the injury heal quickly so the player can continue to play." Except the injuries caused by repeated concussions don't heal. Patrick Risha suffered CTE ( chronic traumatic encephalopathy), and brain damage, especially repeated brain damage doesn't heal.

roseberry, when my middle son was in 10th grade he brought home a form for me to sign, giving him permission to play football and relieving the school of liability for any injuries he sustained. I refused to sign and he was really, really angry with me for several months. But now he is glad I didn't sign and he didn't play football.

(He did join the baseball team, and got hit in the jaw by a bat while he was serving as a catcher. Six stitches, and the scar still shows 30 years later and he has to be careful when shaving around it. But his brain works just fine.)
Tell your friends to stay clear-eyed and fight for their kids' lives. This one is easy; it's well inside the line.
no thanks. i always went for the geeks.

Please keep these articles coming.

It is one of the few ways we can stop the onslaught of damaged kids.

For what?

For our entertainment.
Every time one of these stories is printed, i make this comment: why not flag football? Same sport, but it's fun instead of terrifying.
You missed one myth: that playing football has any significant educational value.
It is clear what happens to him.  He commits suicide.   As described he hangs himself with his dogs leash while on the phone or soon after with his mother.

Important clarification: Ali has Parkinson's Disease, which has caused his devastating motor symptoms. Traumatic brain injury may be a contributing factor to some cases of Parkinson's, but plenty of people with PD never boxed, and plenty of old boxers didn't get PD.

It was Muhammad Ali who stopped me watching football. (I started watching the Baltimore Colts with Johhny Unitas and was devoted to the 49ers in the Bill Walsh years.) I haven't watched even a Superbowl in four years now. Watching the quickest man who ever walked become mumbling made me realize that the price of head-impact is just too awful to call it entertainment.

Very few high school athletes receive scholarships to play a sport in college. Many high school athletic directors for at least the last 10 years have been stressing to parents that the college bills are extremely unlikely to be paid as a result of their child's athletic prowess. Whether they believe it or not, who knows. Ivy League schools such as Harvard do not offer athletic scholarships. However, they are so well endowed that they now simply pay the tuition for all students who can't foot the bill. Therefore, top athletes who couldn't afford to go to an Ivy League school before now can. And Ivy League schools are winning like they've never won before.
OK, the football players are admitted to the good schools.  But what happens after that?  Do they actually get the good education those names represent, or are they merely being exploited?

Sara--the athletes don't need to be mediocre for the poster's statement to be true. Merely less academically able than the students admitted on academic talent alone. Will you deny that this is the case?

It pains me to have to tell my son that even though he is a highly gifted, straight A, piano virtuoso and all around great kid, he is less likely to get into an elite university than the star football, basketball, soccer or lacrosse players in his school who have average grades and act like jerks. When even the nation's most elite colleges admit kids based on their athletic rather than academic prowess, what do you think is the message being sent to parents and kids? Hey kids, want to get into Harvard or Stanford on a full ride? Play a sport and play it hard! Studying is for suckers!

The character that is built is centered on the idea that the student is somehow superior to others and worthy of praise because he can dominate others through intimidation, aggression and outright violence. Achieving excellence is great, when it is excellence in something productive or creative, something with meaning. Competitive sports glorify domination in activities which have no intrinsic value. In fact a football, baseball, or basketball team is pretty much nothing without losers to make them look like "winners".

My heart goes out to Karen Zinzle Zegel. (I also lived within earshot of the Central Bucks West football field. You can't escape the cheers or loudspeaker commentary.)

Athletic achievement remains an admirable goal.

Athletic achievement doesn't (and should never) require blows to the head.

well, a hundred years ago, it must have been worse played with leather helmets and I'm only guessing here little if any padding.
Besides who was keeping track through any kind of research that
head trauma and dementia could be connected.

what is your point? the city of Syracuse is mad for the orange and
and the majority of players are Black.
maybe misplaced. aggressions.

Football is brutal, a sport of gladiators placing themselves at peril. More than that football is religion. Less than that it is a distraction, a circus and a means to riches for a few.

I see two players running into each other at terrific speed-- two players, each well above 200 pound traveling at 20 mph and crashing...add it up, it's a 40 mph traumatic assault on these bodies. The excitement and athleticism are amazing and the destruction is tragic. Honestly, I see the allure, the hero worship then read a story such as this and think again; the lives of these athletes are disposable, subsumed by the spectacle.

"Curiously missing is the essential statistic of how many play football and do not get CTE."

That statistic was not "curiously missing." The intent of this article was to give the story of one family whose son definitely was diagnosed with CTE after he committed suicide, It was not a statistical survey of the extent of the problem,as you seem to require.

Nevertheless, the NFL has acknowledged that one out of three pro football players may eventually experience some kind of brain trauma (not necessarily only CTE). This of course includes men who have been playing football since childhood, as most professional players have. By the time a player enters the NFL they may have been playing for 10-12 years.

http://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/13/sports/football/actuarial-reports-in-n...

The NY Times would do well to shine a light on the fact that cities around the country pass the bill to taxpayers for a new stadium even though they are used by privately owned football teams making millions.

We all are part of this problem of abusing other human beings for our entertainment. The only way to stop this cruelty is to boycott the advertisers who use college and NFL games to sell their products.
After all only about a tenth of the population watches football, yet we all pay for it in the form of increased prices we pay at the checkout counter. It is time to stop this madness.
Do the young ever really understand the implications of long-term damage I wonder.
